content:
AUSTRALIA

APA Group (APA AT) - Co. signed 3yr extension of gas transportation agreement with Incitec Pivot (IPL AT). (Newswires)

Charter Hall Group (CHC AT) - Co. is said to have acquired 19.9% stake in Australian Unity Property Fund and may be considering a potential takeover. (AFR)

News Corp (NWS AT) - Co. is to cut 50 positions in Australia including 50% of staff in Victoria. (AFR)

Financials - Australian Treasurer Frydenberg told the Big 4 banks to pass on in full any interest rate cut to stimulate the economy. (AFR)

 

JAPAN

Mazda (7261 JT) - Co. May North American sales fell 16% Y/Y to 25.2K units. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Motors (7211 JT) - Co. US May sales rose 4.6% Y/Y to 9.75K units. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT) - Co. is planning investment of JPY 120bln into Nagasaki CMOS production. (Newswires)

Telecoms - Japan's government will allow the major mobile firms to set up 5G base stations on traffic signals as it hopes to reduce the cost and time it takes to roll out the ultrafast networks by taking advantage of the nation's high density of traffic lights. (Nikkei)

Retailers - Japan is to require stores to charge for plastic bags. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Asiana Airlines (020560 KS) - Korean Air Lines (003490 KS) Chairman said they are looking into the Co. which has been put up for sale by its parent. (Yonhap)

Hyundai Motors (005380 KS) - Co. May car sales fell 7.7% Y/Y to 357.5K units and its North America sales rose 2% Y/Y to 66.1K units. (Newswires)

Kia Motors (000270 KS) - Co. May car sales fell 1.6% Y/Y to 1.11mln units and its America May sales rose 4.7% Y/Y to 60.1K units. (Newswires)

Samsung Biologics (207940 KS) - Prosecutors reportedly found evidence was destroyed on CEO’s computer. (Yonhap)

Other News - South Korea officially announced the beginning of FTA negotiations with the Philippines on Monday. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump tweeted that China is subsidizing its products in order that it can continue to be sold in the USA and reiterated that many firms are leaving China for other countries including the US to avoid paying the tariffs. (Twitter)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US hopes were dashed by China's human rights behaviour following Tiananmen Square and urged China to release human rights prisoners on anniversary of Tiananmen Square protest crackdown. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

US President Trump suggested that a big US-UK trade deal is possible once UK gets rid of the shackles of the EU, while he added that the US and UK are already starting to talk. (Twitter)

  • UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (May) 49.4 vs. Exp. 52 (Prev. 53.1). (Newswires)
  • EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (May) 47.7 vs. Exp. 47.7 (Prev. 47.7)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih said Saudi Arabia is committed to do whatever is required to stabilise oil markets and that he is confident based on discussion with several oil producers that we will do what is required to keep market stability after June by drawing inventories down from their current elevated levels. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said Russia is committed to sticking to the OPEC+ deal in June and that Russia's combined production cut under the deal stood at 317k BPD in May compared to October levels (11.36mln BPD). (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Bullard (Voter, Dove) said an interest rate cut might be warranted soon on trade and inflation worries, while he added that inversion of yield suggests current policy rate setting is inappropriately high and that trade uncertainty means expected slowdown in the US may now be even slower. (Newswires)

Mexico President AMLO said he wants to continue being a friend of US President Trump and is optimistic that a deal can be reached with the US. In related news, Mexico’s Foreign Minister said officials are to meet with USTR Lighthizer and acting US Homeland Security Secretary McAleenan this week and that imposing tariffs on Mexican imports could be counterproductive to stopping immigration flows, while the Deputy Foreign Minister noted that US tariffs on Mexico puts the approval of USMCA at risk. (Newswires)

US House Judiciary Committee launched antitrust probe into tech industry including Google (GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and others. As a reminder, there were earlier reports that the DoJ is preparing an antitrust investigation of Google and was also given jurisdiction for potential anti-trust probe of Apple as part of broader tech review. (Newswires)

  • US Markit Manufacturing PMI Final 50.5 (Prev. 50.6). (Newswires)
  • US ISM Manufacturing PMI (May) 52.1 vs. Exp. 53.0 (Prev. 52.8)
  • US ISM Manufacturing Prices Paid (May) 53.2 vs. Exp. 52.0 (Prev. 50.0)
  • US ISM Manufacturing Employment Idx (May) 53.7 vs. Exp. 52.5 (Prev. 52.4)

 

MARKET RECAP

Key FAANG names sunk on Monday, as the US government moved to take on big tech. The DoJ are preparing anti-trust investigations into Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) and possibly Apple (AAPL), both of whose shares sunk on the news. FTC, who reportedly formed an agreement dividing antitrust jurisdiction with the DoJ, secured the right to investigate both Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook (FB) on an anti-trust basis (whose shares also sunk on the news). Boeing (BA) shares were under pressure on the news that the aircraft maker had informed the Federal Aviation Administration that certain 737 MAX and 737NG wing components [leading edge slats] may have been improperly manufactured. Merck (MRK) caught a bid after releasing positive results in its latest KEYTRUDA study, in which 5-year survival rates were significantly higher than in previously treated patients. Amgen (AMGN) jumped higher at the open after news emerged that one of the pharma co.’s new drug had shrunk “undruggable” cancer tumours in half of patients. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) moved lower on worries that the US/Mexico trade spat could affect the Mexican food makers profit margins. FedEx (FDX) was under pressure after China announced over the weekend that they look into the US postal service after Huawei reported it had misdirected packages. Centene (CNC) stock price tumbled after Humana (HUM) dismissed speculation that they were looking to take over the former. Humana jumped higher. Centene (CNC) shares sunk after Humana (HUM) made an unusual SEC filing which dismissed market speculation that Humana was looking to buy Centene. Humana (HUM) moved higher. S&P 500 -0.3% at 2744, NASDAQ-100 -2.1% at 6978, Dow Jones 0% at 24819.

Treasuries continued their march higher on Monday. The rally was initiated by disappointing UK and EZ Markit Manufacturing PMI, where the bid in Gilts and Bunds seeped across the pond; it worth highlighting that Bund yields reached their all-time lows as German manufacturing remained in the contractionary zone. Analysts note that the reaching of multi-year lows in several US yields sparked some dealer sales and profit taking, where the 30-year posted 31-month lows. However, a mixed release of the US Markit Manufacturing PMI saw the rally continue in the US session, which was then exacerbated by Fed’s Bullard warranting the idea of a rate cut. At settlement, the curve had bull steepened considerably, where the 2s/30s widened by c. 5.5bps, and the 2-year yield dropped by more than 10bps. US T-note futures (M9) settled 16+ higher ticks at 126-28+.

US MARKET WRAP - 3rd JUNE 2019: FAANG names lead stocks lower; Bullard mulls a rate cute
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equites down, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude down.

* REAR VIEW: US govt moves to take on Big tech, who lead NDX lower, Mixed US ISM, Dovish Bullard, China ramps up trade rhetoric, Bund yields hit fresh record low, Russia to extend output cuts

* COMING UP: RBA Policy Meeting, AU Retail Sales, EZ (flash) CPI, Unemployment Rate, US Durable Goods, UK Construction PMI, Federal Reserve Inflation Conference, US API, RBA’s Lowe, Fed’s Williams, Evans, Powell, Kaplan, Brainard

* US/MEXICO: Mexico Foreign Minister says imposing tariffs on Mexican imports could be counterproductive to stopping immigration flows. He also noted that Mexican officials are to meet with USTR Lighthizer and acting US Homeland Security Secretary McAleenan this week, but the extent concessions to the US are limited by "dignity" whilst the Mexican Deputy Foreign Minister commented that the US tariffs on Mexico puts at risk the approval of USMCA. Mexican President Obrador was more conciliatory, saying he wants to continue being a friend of US President Trump and is optimistic that a deal can be reached with the US. US President Trump later said that, as a sign of good faith, Mexico should immediately stop the flow of people and drugs across the US/Mexico border. Finally, in the last hour of trade, reports emerged suggesting Mexico is mulling retaliation against the US should tariffs proceed.

* CHINA WHITE PAPER: China’s State Council overnight released a White Paper on trade, again hitting back at the US and suggesting they were the party that backtracked on three occasions during trade talks (March 2018, May 2018, May 2019) – up until the most recent ‘backtracking’, the two parties had reached a broad consensus on the majority of trade issues, China claimed. China said the remaining issues could not be resolved since the US was insisting on “mandatory requirements concerning China’s sovereign affairs,” as well as refusing to lift tariffs immediately. The paper insinuated that China has enough firepower to continue fighting the trade war. The paper went on to state that China would continue economic reforms and opening up its economy. The paper was released as Chinese counter-tariffs on around USD 60bln of US goods went into effect over the weekend. There were no details given on any potential meetings between China President Xi and US President Trump at the upcoming G20 meeting on 28-29 June. Net/net, the implications seem to be that neither side is seeking to de-escalate trade tensions for now, and the bar to success for any future meetings seems high.

* CHINA TARGETS FEDEX: China's will probe FedEx (FDX) on suspicion of undermining the legitimate rights and interests of Chinese clients, China state news agency Xinhua reported on the weekend, alleging that FedEx failed to deliver packages to designated addresses in China, “seriously damaging the lawful rights and interests of its clients and violating laws and regulations governing the express industry in China.” The news followed claims by Chinese telecoms giant Huawei said parcels intended for it were diverted. The WSJ reported that changes at FedEx (FDX) to comply with US trade restrictions reportedly lead to the misrouting of two packages for Huawei.

* FED: Fed's Bullard (voter, dovish) said an interest rate cut might be warranted soon due to concerns regarding trade and inflation. Bullard also said that the inversion of yield supports his case for further rates (Bullard has heavily warned in the past that the yield curve is a good predictor of future downturns). The dovish fed voter also said that trade uncertainty meant that the expected slowdown in the US might now be even steeper before later noting during a Q/A session that he expects trade uncertainty to continue for foreseeable future and his recent visit to Hong Kong left him more pessimistic about a trade deal. In the wake of Bullard's comments, SPX saw positive ticks, as did the T-Note, while the USD fell toward new session lows (the reaction was short-lived, as AAPL news broke shortly afterwards, unwinding the Bullard Bounce). Analyst chat about 'insurance rate cuts' has picked up following the dovish comments from Fed's Clarida and Kashkari last week, with Bullard adding fuel to that fire on Monday. Overnight, Fed non-voter Daly toed the median line, noting the strength of the US economy, reiterating a ‘patient’ stance. Fed's Quarles (voter) and Fed's Barkin (non-voter) stayed away from current monetary policy/economic outlook comments.

* US/AUSTRALIA TRADE: The Trump administration considered imposing tariffs on imports from Australia last week, but decided against the move amid fierce opposition from military officials and the State Department, according to several people familiar with the discussions, NYT reported. However, US President Trump played down suggestions in NYT regarding tariffs on Australia.

* TRUMP ECONOMY ADIVOR HASSETT TO LEAVE: Kevin Hassett is set to leave his role as CEA Chair, Bloomberg reported. Hassett said his decision was not related to Mexico tariffs, and had been in the works for a while.

* ITALY/EUROPE: Finance Minister Tria insisted Italy was not seeking confrontation with the EU, remarks that appear at odds with commentary from other members of his party, analysts observed. Tria also said Italy would remain within its 2.4% deficit/GDP target, though analysts remain sceptical. EU Commissioner Moscovici continued to call for dialogue. However, Italy Deputy PM Salvini opted to continue the recent tough talks; saying the jobless rate, not the EU deficit, must dictate whether Italy can raise government spending before adding that when the unemployment rate falls below 5%, Italy will comply with rules. Italy PM Conte, in a scheduled speech, said that EU rules will stay in force until the government can secure changes whilst EU disciplinary action would be very bad for Italy. He said that the coalition leaders need to decide if they continue want to with the government or pursue an election whilst saying that he will do his best to protect Italian interests in EU negotiations.

* GERMANY COALITION FRAGILE: Bund yields fell to fresh record lows amid the risk-off, as well as after weekend news that SPD leader Nahles, a junior coalition partner, had stepped-down following a soft performance in the recent European elections. Accordingly, speculation about the collapse of the German government has been rife on Monday, potentially leading to elections. This will depend on whom the SPD replaces Nahles with. However, RBC’s analysts note that while the uncertainty would add to global risks, there is a possibility that it leads to a less fiscally conservative government – for instance, if the Greens were to form part of the government (a weekend poll saw them leading, ahead of Merkel’s CDU).

* GEOPOLITCAL: US Secretary of State Pompeo said on Monday that the US and Europe should work together to ensure Europe has a secure and diversified energy supply; this comes amidst pressure from Washington for Europe to ensure it doesn’t bypass US interests by importing Iranian crude, where Europe had previously mulled the use of a special purpose vehicle to do so. Elsewhere on the Iran front, China has called for the full implementation of the JCPOA, the nuclear deal that the US wants to abandon in order to renegotiate.

* US MANUFACTURING ISM: May ISM data was a mixed bag; the downtrend for the headline continues, with a 31-month low of 52.1 (expected 53.0 vs prior 52.8). However, the breakdown was more encouraging: new orders rose by 1 point to 52.7 (welcome news consider the Markit manufacturing PMI, released fifteen minutes before the ISM, saw new orders falling into contraction for the first time since August 2009), ahead of NFP this week, the manufacturing employment sub-component was up (+1.2 points to 53.7), and prices rose to 53.2 from 50 (cons 52.5). "While both orders and production are expanding steadily, the manufacturing sector has undoubtedly hit a soft patch in Q2 amid the recent increase in tariffs vis-à-vis China and now Mexico," Oxford Economics said, "we do not expect a rapid rebound in activity in the months ahead." The consultancy notes that while underlying domestic fundamentals remain strong, they are cooling as fiscal stimulus dissipates. OxEco also notes that "while global central banks have adopted a much more dovish stance, the international growth landscape still looks fragile," and the consultancy now sees the Fed's next move as a rate cut in the early part of 2020.

* CHINA MANUFACTURING PMI: The Caixin manufacturing PMI – which tends to be a good read on smaller, private companies – saw a slight upside surprise (unchanged at 50.2, CONSENSUS 50.0); Markit reported that total new work rose at a quicker pace, and was underpinned by a rise in export sales. Production, meanwhile, was steady.

* EUROZONE MANUFATURING PMI: The headline slipped further into sub-50 territory (47.7 in line with consensus, prev. 47.9; Germany confirmed at 50.6, France confirmed at 44.3; Italy rose but remains sub-50, while Spain is a touch above that neutral line). New orders fell for the eighth consecutive month. A decline in work backlogs and delivery times could hint at more slack in the labour market, and the employment sub-component saw a fall after 56 months of consecutive gains.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 16+ HIGHER TICKS AT 126-28+: Treasuries continued their march higher on Monday. The rally was initiated by disappointing UK and EZ Markit Manufacturing PMI, where the bid in Gilts and Bunds seeped across the pond; it worth highlighting that Bund yields reached their all-time lows as German manufacturing remained in the contractionary zone. Analysts note that the reaching of multi-year lows in several US yields sparked some dealer sales and profit taking, where the 30-year posted 31-month lows. However, a mixed release of the US Markit Manufacturing PMI saw the rally continue in the US session, which was then exacerbated by Fed’s Bullard warranting the idea of a rate cut. At settlement, the curve had bull steepened considerably, where the 2s/30s widened by c. 5.5bps, and the 2-year yield dropped by more than 10bps.

* WTI (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.25 LOWER AT USD 53.25/BBL; BRENT (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.71 LOWER AT USD 61.28/BBL: The crude complex traded choppy after paring back earlier gains going into the US session on Monday. Prices were on the backfoot in early trade before catching a bid after Saudi Arabia said it would do what it takes to stabilise the oil market, mentioning the need to for draws in inventories; in addition reports of Saudi’s production currently at 9.65mln BPD. However, the oil market’s growing correlation to equity markets dictated later trade, where US equity markets reversed into the red and crude following suit. Energy analysts at Citi comment, “the larger issue here is that the bullish theme of OPEC+ production restraint and geopolitical risk to supply that lifted prices from January-April are no longer as persuasive.” Elsewhere, Russian Energy Minister Novak announced that Russia would be committing to the OPEC+ deal in June (previous reports had suggested the oil major was hesitant, but it’s worth noting this was before the recent harsh sell off in crude). Novak also said that Russia’s combined production cut under the deal stood at 317k BPD beneath the October levels of 11.36mln BPD, above its current quota of 228k BPD; the contamination of oil in the Druzhba pipeline is likely to have forced Russia’s hand somewhat. Sticking to the Druzhba pipeline, following a meeting between Russian energy authorities, Poland's PKN Orlen said clean oil supply to Poland via the pipeline can be re-instated as of June 10th; adding that Russia's Transneft will pay oil producers so they can compensate their customers' losses. Looking ahead to this week's US energy inventory data: crude stocks are seen drawing 0.2mln bbls; both products are seen building, with distillates up by 0.4mln, and gasoline stocks up by 0.7mln bbls.

* S&P 500 -0.3% at 2744, NASDAQ-100 -2.1% at 6978, Dow Jones 0% at 24819; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -1.2%, Consumer Staples 1.3%, Energy 1.4%, Financials 0.7%, Health Care 0.3%, Industrials 0.7%, Information Technology -1.8%, Materials 3.2%, Telecommunication Services -2.8%, Utilities 1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Key FAANG names sunk on Monday, as the US government moved to take on big tech. The DoJ are preparing anti-trust investigations into Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) and possibly Apple (AAPL), both of whose shares sunk on the news. FTC, who reportedly formed an agreement dividing antitrust jurisdiction with the DoJ, secured the right to investigate both Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook (FB) on an anti-trust basis (whose shares also sunk on the news). Boeing (BA) shares were under pressure on the news that the aircraft maker had informed the Federal Aviation Administration that certain 737 MAX and 737NG wing components [leading edge slats] may have been improperly manufactured. Merck (MRK) caught a bid after releasing positive results in its latest KEYTRUDA study, in which 5-year survival rates were significantly higher than in previously treated patients. Amgen (AMGN) jumped higher at the open after news emerged that one of the pharma co.’s new drug had shrunk “undruggable” cancer tumours in half of patients. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) moved lower on worries that the US/Mexico trade spat could affect the Mexican food makers profit margins. FedEx (FDX) was under pressure after China announced over the weekend that they look into the US postal service after Huawei reported it had misdirected packages. Centene (CNC) stock price tumbled after Humana (HUM) dismissed speculation that they were looking to take over the former. Humana jumped higher. Centene (CNC) shares sunk after Humana (HUM) made an unusual SEC filing which dismissed market speculation that Humana was looking to buy Centene. Humana (HUM) moved higher.

* FX DAILY WRAP: EUR shrugged off weak manufacturing PMI (which continues to move into contraction territory) and was higher, with Bund/UST yield differentials also favouring the single currency, as well as seasonal effects more supportive (according to SocGen); DXY downside also supported. DXY was under pressure as Markit and ISM manufacturing PMI disappointed somewhat, while there is now increasing speculation that the Fed will need to make an insurance rate cut; a dovish Bullard in afternoon trade gave further credence to this notion. GBP was unable to benefit from a weaker dollar on the day; as Markit Manufacturing PMI came in well below expectations (and in contractionary territory), and politics continues to be noisy. JPY is slightly up amid escalating trade wars, though the 108.00 level has, for now, held.AUD and NZD were buoyed by better than expected Caixin PMI data out of China overnight, as well as the. Markets look ahead to tonight RBA meeting (a 25bps cut is 95% priced in), while short-positioning remains towards extremes; participants are looking to the RBA for guidance into the aggressiveness of the easing cycle will be. CAD was firm as a function of dollar weakness, strengthening despite poor Mfg PMI and the crude complex coming off. BRL shrugged-off weaker PMI data, moving higher on political optimism after the FT reported that support for pension reform is growing in both Houses. MXN remained on the defensive, as US/Mexico trade concerns lingered despite a conciliatory sounding Mexican President Obrador.

Daily FX Wrap: DXY pulls back further from 98.00 whilst USD/MXN eyes 20.00 on tariff troubles
content:
DXY

A downbeat start to the week for the USD as the index saw downside throughout the day ahead of the Markit and ISM Manufacturing data in which the former marginally eased and employment rose at the slowest rate since March 2017. Meanwhile, the ISM headline figure missed expectations (52.1 vs. Exp. 53.0) but the components were optimistic with manufacturing employment index and prices paid topping estimates whilst new orders index improved from the prior. DXY was choppy post-data after having fluctuated within a USD 97.50-80 band throughout the day. Looking ahead, tomorrow sees the release of US Durables (R), whilst on the speaker front, Fed voters Evans, Williams, Brainard and Chair Powell are on the docket.

 

NZD/AUD/CAD

The antipodeans remain the G10 outperformers amid a continuation from the optimistic Caixin manufacturing data coupled with a receding Dollar ahead of the RBA’s much anticipated 25bps cut to its Cash Rate (full preview available in the Research Suite). Participants are on the look-out for guidance into the aggressiveness of the easing cycle, with the potential for limited downside movement in the AUD/USD as markets have priced in “too much short” in the AUD, as according to UBS. AUD/USD is set to end the EU session closer to the top of a 0.6926-64 range with clean air to the upside until the psych 0.7000 level, whilst the downside sees psych support at 0.6850. Meanwhile, the Kiwi was bolstered by the aforementioned Chinese data and fared better than its antipodean counterpart as the AUD/NZD cross remained below its 200 DMA at 1.0624 and hovered around the 1.0600 level ahead of its 50 DMA at 1.0571. Finally, USD/CAD is back below the 1.3500 (vs. an intraday high of 1.3527), with the decline in the USD and firmer oil prices outmuscling downbeat Canadian manufacturing PMI, with decent support seen at 1.3482 (May 28th low) ahead of another support at 1.3425 (May 27th low).

 

EUR/GBP

Ultimately firmer on the day, again potentially as a function of a receding Buck, after little reaction was experienced amid unrevised French, German and EZ manufacturing PMIs. EUR/USD is set to end the EU session around the 1.1200 level (vs. low of 1.1157), ahead of its 50 DMA at 1.1208. Looking ahead, EZ flash inflation figures are due to be released tomorrow with headline expected to cool to 1.3% from 1.7%. Meanwhile, UK’s manufacturing sector slipped into contraction, with new orders and employment both declining whilst stockpiling paused following the Brexit delay. In terms of Brexit developments, and increasing number new members line up for the Tory leadership, with the latest from Environmental Sectary Gove, a front runner, reportedly considering a further extension beyond October 31st, whilst leading candidate Johnson said that if he is elected, the UK will leave the bloc with or without a deal on Brexit day. GBP/USD set to end the EU day little changed around the 1.2630 mark with little by way of near-term technicals.

 

CHF/JPY

A divergence is seen in the safe haven currencies, with the Franc firmer on the day and below parity vs the Buck, albeit off lows after the pair bounced off support at its 200 DMA (0.9958). Meanwhile, USD/JPY is set to end the EU session in the green, potentially on an unwind in Yen position as US stocks crawled back into positive territory throughout the day. USD/JPY is poised to end the EU session around 108.50, having opened around 108.28.

 

EM

Another downbeat day for the Peso in a continuation from Trump’s tariff announcement last week. Rhetoric from Mexico has been less confrontational in comparison to the US, although the Mexican Foreign Minister did note that tariff increase threatens the USMCA deal. USD/MXN is poised to conclude EU trade closer to the middle of today’s 19.60-80 range as the Mexican delegation continues talks in Washington. Elsewhere, the Lira has retraced some of last week’s gains, albeit only marginally, with the aid of softer-than-forecast inflation figures which allows the CBRT to start considering a policy ease. USD/TRY is set to end the day back above its 50 DMA (5.8597) having fluctuated within a 5.83-89 intraday band.

Fixed Income Update: EU, UK and US debt futures trade in middle of session ranges
content:
Core EU and UK debt have come off of session highs as the trade & PMI-driven futures lift seems to have been short-lived rather than session defining. Both Gilt and Bund 10yr futures trade in the middle of session ranges, with action overshadowed by Italian debt. BTP 10yr futures have continued to climb throughout the session and are the mainland outperformer, trading in close proximity to session highs of 130.91 ahead of a planned speech by PM Conte in the EU afternoon, who has “big things to say” after suggestions of further political upheaval in Rome.

Turning to the US, debt futures have seen similar price action when compared to their core EU and UK counterparts, with the 10yr benchmark in the middle of the session range of 126-10 to 126-30. Some upside was offered, however, by the disappointing Markit PMI data with the New Orders Index falling to contractionary territory for first time since August 2009. ISM Manufacturing was also disappointing, but the benchmark was more reticent to react considering some sub-components (incl. new orders) were more encouraging.

Talking Crude: Saudi to do whatever it takes
content:
• Bullish comments from Saudi has pushed crude markets back into the green to start the week following earlier losses. Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih stated that the Kingdom is committed to do whatever is required to stabilise oil markets; adding that he is confident, based on discussion with several oil producers, that they will do what is required to keep market stability after June, more specifically, by drawing inventories. Also, out of Saudi were reports that its production level is currently at 9.65mln BPD, down from the previous 10.05mln, keeping well below its OPEC+ cut quota of 10.3mln.
  • In recent weeks oil has been taking its cues from the faltering global demand outlook, particularly the sell off in SPX. Analysts at SEB comment, “The market is now trading oil on the basis of learning from last year: Oil = S&P 500.” The note goes on to suggest that there is “significant risk that the market is overselling Brent crude,” highlighting that fundamentals differ this time around due to OPEC+’s commitment to cutting supply. On a similar vein, Goldman suggest that, “A still tight EU crude market, the suddenness of the move lower, OPEC’s reluctance to increase supply and our economists above consensus growth forecast all suggest prices may recover from here.” Goldman caveats their statement saying that due to macro and US inventory headwinds, prices should remain around their Q3 forecasts (USD 65/bbl for Brent), “albeit with still high price volatility.”
  • Speculators cut their WTI net long positions by 38k contracts to 212k and Brent speculators cut their net long positions by 41k to 353k in the most recent week, Reuters energy analyst John Kemp highlights this being “the heaviest one-week selling since October 2018.” Kemp notes that from a positioning perspective, in the six major petroleum futures and options (Brent, WTI, US gasoline, US heating oil and Euro gasoil), where hedge fund long positions outnumber shorts by a ratio of 5:1 (down from the year’s peak of just under 9:1, but still exceeding the low of 2:1 at the beginning of the year), “some but not all the downside risk has been reduced by the sale of excess bullish positions.”

DOW

Merck (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) says its KEYTRUDA drug demonstrated a five-year survival rate of 23.2%, vs 15.5% in previously treated patients. Elsewhere, Merck and AstraZeneca (AZN LN) presented results from their Phase 3 POLO trail, evaluating LYNPARZA, which showed a statistically significant and clinically meaningful improvement in progression-free survival for the drug.

Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) has informed the Federal Aviation Administration that certain 737 MAX and 737NG wing components [leading edge slats] may have been improperly manufactured, FAA are planning to issue an order requiring operators of the plans worldwide to identify and replace the improper parts. Reportedly, 179 Max aircraft and 133 NG planes are affected. FAA state that complete failure of the components would not result in aircraft loss but could lead to in-flight damage. In response, Boeing has notified plane operators and is sending replacement parts. Elsewhere, Malaysia Airlines is reportedly reviewing its order for 25 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft "very carefully" and says plans for the first delivery in July 2020 could be delayed.

Goldman Sachs’s (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) merchant banking unit is to acquire Capital Vision Services LP, a private equity firm who manages MrEyeDr optometry centres, in a deal worth USD 2.7bln as the co. looks to bolster their portfolio in the healthcare services sector. Elsewhere, HSBC (HSBA) is to replace Goldman Sachs as its broker, following a review by HSBC CFO Stevenson.

Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) is expected to announce the end of iTunes today, with the move believed to come as the company moves away from the iPhone as its core product and looks to develop its subscription businesses. iTunes functions will reportedly now be divided between three new applications. In other news, a Piper Jaffray survey revealed “a surprisingly high amount of interest” in 5G iPhones, leading to analyst Michael Olson to maintain his overweight rating for the firm. Elsewhere, an independent researcher found that Apple macOS security features can be "easily bypassed", as reported by TechCrunch.

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – The DoJ is preparing an antitrust investigation of Google, with the investigation expected to probe the internet giant’s practises related to search and other businesses. Elsewhere, Google faced an outage on Sunday which temporarily brought down YouTube, Snapchat and Gmail, amongst other online services.

Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) could also face heightened antitrust scrutiny, due to a new agreement between US regulators that is set to put the ecommerce giant under closer FTC watch, WaPo reports. Elsewhere, Amazon are to open 10 shops in the UK as part of a pilot test, with the first opening today in Manchester, stores are to help digital businesses with high-street success. Spokesman stated that the co. will not profit from the scheme.

Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) must defend itself in a lawsuit which accuses the social media network of failing to safeguard users’ personal data in the Cambridge Analytical scandal. Elsewhere, the social media co. is in talks with US derivatives regulators, the CFTC, over its plans for a digital currency.

Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automakers) is to make the Model Y electric sport utility vehicle at its factory in California as it looks to hit productions volumes quickly. Elsewhere, a Model S caught fire and burnt down at a supercharger station in Belgium.

T-Mobile (TMUS) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecoms Services) and Sprint (S) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecoms Services) have received merger approval from Hawaii’s public utilities commission.

S&P 500

CVS Health (CVS) (Health Care/Health Care Services) is preparing to defend its USD 70bln acquisition Aetna on Tuesday in front of investors and a federal judge.

FedEx (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) is to face a probe by the Chinese government after Huawei claims that the co. redirected deliveries to the wrong address.

Carnival Corp (CCL) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) is to ask a US court to dismiss lawsuits claiming that it benefitted from confiscated properties in Cuba, after such cases were made possible by the trump administration last month.

Blackstone (BX) (Real Estate/Office REITs) is to buy U.S. industrial warehouse properties from Singapore-based logistics provider GLP for USD 18.7bln.

Humana (HUM) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) confirmed it will not propose a merger with Centene (CNC), ahead of Centene’s acquisition of WellCare (WCG), in response to significant market speculation.

General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) has backed off of plans to close its Belfort, France factory after previously announcing it would cut over 1000 jobs.

AT&T’s (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) is facing criticism from US President Trump who is currently in the UK, where he called the telecoms giant’s CNN “fake news” and urged the owner of AT&T to provide a greater variety of US news coverage to the UK audience.

American Airlines Group Inc (AAL) (Industrials/Airlines) - The U.S. Transportation Department is expected to provide tentative approval to a bid by the US airline and Aussie peer Qantas Airways, who seek to operate a joint venture.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) (Consumer Discretionary/Casinos & Gaming), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) (Consumer Discretionary/Casinos & Gaming) – Gaming revenue in Macau hit a five-month high in May, increasing 1.8% YY to 25.95bln patacas.

OTHER

Novartis (NOVN SW, NVS) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) has reported statistically significant survival results for Kisqali when used in combination with endocrine therapy.

Renault (RNO FP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automakers), Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM, FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Automakers) - In a bid to persuade the French government to back the proposed merger, Fiat Chrysler is discussing; a special dividend for Renault, stronger job guarantees, that the combined company's operations would be headquartered in France and giving the French state a seat on the joint venture’s board.

Twitter (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has apologised for the closing of accounts critical to the Chinese government in the lead up to the 30th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square protests. Elsewhere, the social media platform has bought Fabula AI as it looks to strengthen its Machine Learnings capabilities.

Infineon (IFN GY) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) is to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) in a deal worth EUR 9bln.

KKR & Co Inc (KKR) (Financials/Capital Markets) is to explore the potential USD 2bln sale of its Singapore Goodpack.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 3rd June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices remain subdued [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.1%] but have grinded higher after a downbeat Asia-Pac lead as China issued a White Paper blaming the US for the deterioration in trade talks
  • In FX, the DXY remains below the 98.0 handle and relatively unchanged for the session ahead of key risk events throughout the week
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US mfg PMIs, ISM mfg PMI, Fed’s Quarles, Barkin and Bullard

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded negatively with risk appetite subdued as the US faces a 2-front trade war against China and Mexico, although stronger than expected Caixin PMI data helped limit losses in China. Nonetheless, a risk averse tone was seen from the reopen after China released a white paper that blamed the US for the setback of trade talks which pressured US equity futures to extend on the losses from Wall St’s worst May performance since 2010. ASX 200 (-1.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.9%) declined with the energy sector the underperformer in Australia after the recent oil slump, while safe-haven currency flows weighed on Tokyo stocks and with weakness in SoftBank exacerbated on reports of funding difficulties for its next USD 100bln tech fund. Hang Seng (U/C) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were initially higher after the PBoC maintained net liquidity through CNY 80bln of reverse repos and after Chinese Caixin Manufacturing topped estimates, although the gains were short-lived as trade concerns remained heavily in focus with China playing the blame game, while it is also set to draft its own blacklist of 'unreliable' entities and probe FedEx over possible infringement of Huawei’s legal rights regarding rerouted packages. Finally, 10yr JGBs were steady with only marginal gains seen despite the widespread risk aversion and the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 800bln in up to 5yr JGBs.

China State Council Information Office released a white paper which formalized its position on trade negotiations and stated that the US government bears the responsibility for setback in trade talks, while it also noted that China does not want a trade war but is not afraid of one either. However, China also suggested negotiations remain a priority and State Councillor/Defence Minister Wei Fenghe said both sides should follow the consensus by the 2 heads of state and promote a relationship involving coordination, cooperation and stability, while a researcher at the state-backed think tank China Center for International Economic Exchanges suggested China “is expressing its wish to work together”. (Newswires/WSJ)

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repo for a net neutral position on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8896 (Prev. 6.8992)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (May) 50.2 vs. Exp. 50.0 (Prev. 50.2). (Newswires)

UK officials alleged that a security test on Huawei 5G equipment was rigged by China to make it look safer. (Telegraph)

US

China have issued a warning against academics and students studying in the US, according to State Media; as suggested by Hu Xijin of the Chinese Global Times. (Newswires/Twitter)

US President Trump tweeted that Mexico is sending a big delegation to talk about the border and suggested that the problem is that they’ve been “talking” for 25 years and we want action not talk. President Trump also suggested they could solve the border crisis in one day if they so desired but added that our companies and jobs are coming back to the USA. (Twitter) Furthermore, Trump has confirmed that the US will end preferential trade status for India this week. (BBC)

US President Trump said White House Economic Adviser Hassett will be leaving shortly and that a replacement will be announced when he returns to the US. (Twitter)

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) maintained forecast for economic growth at 2% and said trade discussions are creating uncertainty in the economy, while she added her stance is to be patient and wait what the details of the trade discussions are. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (May) 49.4 vs. Exp. 52 (Prev. 53.1)

- New orders and employment both decline

- Stockpiling activity halts following Brexit date delay

Germany’s SPD party leader and ruling coalition partner Andrea Nahles resigned; German Chancellor Merkel says her coalition government will continue despite the setback. (BBC/Newswires) Subsequently, Germany's SPD propose Schwesig, Dreyer and Schaeffler-Guembel head the SPd temporarily after Nahles stepped down, as according to sources. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte will today launch an ultimatum to the coalition parties to speed up government action or face his resignation, adding that he does not intend to undertake an EU disciplinary procedure. (La Repubblica)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (May) 47.7 vs. Exp. 47.7 (Prev. 47.7)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

US has delayed tougher sanctions on Iran's petrochemical sectors in an attempt to dial back tensions, according to WSJ citing sources. (WSJ)

EQUITIES

Major European indices began the week lower in continuation from the Asia-Pac session which was weighed on by China releasing a white-paper blaming the US for the set back in trade talks and are to draft a ‘black-list’ of unreliable entities. Throughout the mornings trade bourses have been grinding higher but are still in negative territory [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.1%]; sectors are mixed on the day with some moderate outperformance seen in Utilities, which Nomura Quants note is not sufficient to trigger an excessive volatility shock as the sell-off in cyclicals in minimal compared with prior selloffs. Notable movers this morning include Infineon (-6.4%) who are near the bottom of the Stoxx 600 after it was reported that they are to acquire Cypress Semiconductors for an enterprise value of EUR 8bln; Co’s boards have already consented to this acquisition. Elsewhere, airline names are somewhat subdued after reports that the global airline industry is to record its lowest profit in five-years, particularly easyJet (-2.1%) which is also weighed on following reports that the Co. are this week to drop out of the FTSE 100 (-0.4%). At the other end of the Stoxx, and topping the DAX are Wirecard (+2.3%) following the CEO stating they expect an outstanding H1.

FX

DXY - Overall little changed on the day thus far, following on from a relatively subdued session overnight as the index remains sub-98.00 ahead of this week’s key risk events which includes US ISM manufacturing PMI, ECB’s monetary policy meeting and US jobs data. The index remains near the middle of the intraday 97.57-80 range with gains capped by bleeding US yields.

EUR/GBP - Hardly fazed on manufacturing PMI day in which the EZ number was unrevised (as expected) whilst UK’s manufacturing sector slipped into contraction, with new orders and employment both declining whilst stockpiling paused following the Brexit delay. Sterling remains dedicated to Brexit related development as new members line up for the Tory leadership, with the latest from Environmental Sectary Gove, a front runner, reportedly considering a further extension beyond October 31st, whilst leading candidate Johnson said that if he is elected, the UK will leave the bloc with or without a deal on Brexit day. EUR/USD remains within a relatively tight 1.1157-90 range with clean air to the upside until the 1.1200 handle. Beyond that, the pair’s 50 DMA resides around 1.1208 with resistance seen at 1.1264 (May high). Meanwhile, Cable hovers around the 1.2650 mark with little seen to the upside by way of near-term tech levels. 

CHF/JPY - Both firmer on the day, albeit the Yen to a lesser extent, in a continuation of the Trump triggered risk-off mood around the market. USD/JPY fell to whisker away from the 108.00 level (low 108.08) whilst its Franc counterpart slipped further below parity vs. the Greenback. Deutsche Bank recommends “good news rallies should be sold as trade tensions may get relief rallies” as the JPY-crosses “should remain under pressure”. It’s worth keeping in mind USD/JPY sees almost 1bln in option expiries at 108.00-15 ahead of supports at 107.77 and 107.27 (Jan 10 low and 61.8% Fib respectively) whilst USD/CHF sees its 200 DMA at 0.9959 (having already tested the level) ahead of its 200 WMA at 0.9847.

AUD/NZD - Marginally firmer in the aftermath of optimistic China Caixin manufacturing data which provided the antipodeans with some relief following last week’s losses. AUD/USD hovers around the 0.6950 mark (high 0.6960, low 0.6928) despite a looming RBA rate cut, with participants on the look-out for guidance into the aggressiveness of the much-anticipated easing cycle. Meanwhile, its antipodean counterpart seems to be benefiting more as the AUD/NZD cross breached its 200 DMA (1.0624) as it tests the 1.0600 level ahead of its 50 DMA (1.0571)

FIXED INCOME

Fixed income yields have kicked off the day in the red, with slipping yields spurred on by trade once again as the Chinese contingent released their formalized position on trade negotiations, not unsurprisingly blaming the US for the setback. This has seen core EU and UK 10yr debt futures trade with gains of over 20 ticks each. Bunds saw little inspiration from the unrevised manufacturing PMIs in Germany and the EZ, but 10yr Gilt futures surged past their daily peaks to set a new liffe high of 130.04 after UK Manufacturing PMI slipped into contractionary territory as a result of halted stockpiling activity after the Brexit delay.

Moving stateside, futures are higher across the curve with the longer end outperforming and some bull steepening noted. This comes as the aforementioned trade tensions, alongside comments from Fed’s Daly stating that tariffs have contributed to inflation, have driven demand for debt. 10yr yields thus have slipped to their lowest point since 2017 at 2.08%, and 2 year yields are set for their biggest 2 day fall since the crisis, with 23bps already shed. Traders will now be looking forward to the US manufacturing PMI print ahead of potential comments from Fed’s Quarles, Bullard and Barkin.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are recovering off Asia-Pac lows with the former back above the 53.00/bbl handle and climbing towards the next round figure, whilst the latter is attempting to turn positive on the day having already dipped below the 61.00/bbl figure overnight. The weekend saw the release of Russian May crude production which stood at an 11-month low at 11.11mln BPD, down from last month’s 11.24mln BPD, although this was mainly due closures from the Druzbha pipeline due to oil contamination. Elsewhere, Saudi reported a M/M decline in oil output to 9.65mln BPD from the prior 10.05mln BPD, whilst the Kingdom’s energy minister stated that Saudi is committed to do whatever is required to stabilise the oil market. GS takes into account the supply/demand side concerns and net-net expects prices to remain volatile in the coming months, albeit around current levels. Turning to OPEC, the bank sees higher production from Saudi, Russia, UAE and Kuwait to offset Iranian and Venezuelan shortfalls. Thus, GS expects backwardation to persist in the coming months, whilst also revising lower its Q2 Brent forecast to 65.50/bbl from 72.50/bbl, also citing spare capacity created by a new Permian pipeline. Elsewhere, gold (+0.7%) benefits from its safe haven characteristics and extends gains above its 1300/oz level whilst copper prices are seeing some reprieve following last week’s slump as the red metal was underpinned by optimistic Caixin manufacturing data from China.

Goldman Sachs suggest that oil prices may recover from here due to a tight EU crude market, sudden moves lower, OPEC's reluctance to increase supply and above consensus growth forecasts, However, increasingly uncertain macro outlook, rising production an OPEC spare capacity suggests prices at likely to remain around current levels with high volatility. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih states that Saudi Arabia are committed to do whatever is required to stabilise oil markets, adds that he is confident based on discussion with several oil producers that we will do what is required to keep market stability after June, by drawing inventories down from their current elevated levels. (Newswires)

Russian Deputy Energy Minister expects steps to resolve the contaminated oil situation to be carried out as planned. (Newswires)

Norwegian Oil Industry says that a strike would reduce output by 440k BPD. (Newswires)

subject: Russian Deputy Energy Minister expects steps to resolve the contaminated oil situation to be carried out as planned
Nomura Quant: Increasing risk-off trade as US trade/recession concerns intensify
content:
• Nomura note that their indicator of US equity sentiment dropped into negative territory at -1.8 on Friday, as concerns over trade policy were heightened by US President Trump stating he is to instigate tariffs on Mexico from the 10th June at 5%; which appeared to add momentum to risk-off trades. For reference, following this it was reported that USTR Lighthizer and US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin opposed the tariffs on Mexico, which may add to concern around the White House’s approach to trade policy. (RANsquawk)
  • Additionally, Nomura state that the shifting to selling cyclicals and buying defensives have increased, with this seen mainly in Tech and Utilities respectively. This positioning is not seen as being sufficient to trigger an excessive volatility shock, as the sell off of cyclicals, when compared with recent prior selloffs, has been minimal.
  • Looking ahead, Nomura believe that speculators are making trades based on a US recession, if this was to be exacerbated by a poor data print the focus would be on if CTA’s continue their net selling for longer than 7 trading-days; as this would be indicative of the selling no-longer being predominantly technical and therefore market consensus that the  US economy is heading to a recession is increasing.
  • Within FX CTAs are seen as undertaking more risk-averse trades, with long positions in safe-havens increasing versus the USD, particularly USD/JPY shorts which are nearing levels from August 2016, alongside short positions on high-beta currencies.
  • On JPY specifically, Nomura highlight that it would not be unsurprising if USD/JPY fell below the 106.0 handle on systematic buying of the JPY.

Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
BP (BP/ LN) – Co. has agreed to pay around USD 10bln to a businessman involved in a suspicious energy deal, according to an BBC investigation. (BBC)

DCC (DCC LN) – Private equity firm Duke street is nearing a deal to purchase DCC’s generic drug arm with an undisclosed value, according to Sky News citing sources. (Sky News)

William Hill (WMH LN) – Co. reportedly discussed a cash & shares takeover by Caesars Entertainment last year, valuing the Co. at up to GBP 3bln; Caesars Entertainment pulled out of discussions following poor trading. (Times)

Bovis Homes (BVS LN) – Investors from Bovis Homes and Galliford Try have urged the companies to resume merger talks after Galliford Try rejected Bovis’ latest offer. (Newswires) 

Dialog Semiconductor (DLG GY) - Co. to reportedly considering a share buyback this year. (Newswires) 

BASF (BAS GY) – Co. is said to being the sale process for its construction chemical unit, which analysts believe could fetch up to USD 3bln. Furthermore, Bain, Cinven, KKR Carlyle and Standard Industries have reportedly shown interest. (Newswires)

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – Co. have stopped commercial property lending in an attempt to get finances in order. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – AGCOM the Board of Communications Watchdog are to meet to discuss how much access the Co. is granting to their rivals on fixed-line infrastructure competition, along with the associated fees. (Il Messaggero)

Enel (ENEL IM) – Closed the sale of their renewable capacity in Brazil for approximately EUR 660mln. (Newswires)

Mediobanca (MB IM) – Co. have reportedly appointed two executive Vice Chairman to their Corporate & Investment Banking Division. (Newswires)

Astaldi (AST IM) – Paolo Amato has been selected as the Co’s Chief Restructuring Office. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. are reportedly close to the sale of A330 Neo’s to Virgin Atlantic. (Newswires)

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) have received merger approval from Hawaii’s public utilities commission. (Newswires)

Sanofi (SAN FP) – Phase III trial of Isatuximab combination therapy showed a 40% reduction in risk of disease progression or death for patients with myeloma. (Newswires)

Dignity (DTY LN) – FCA are to take on oversight of the funeral sector following concerns that funeral planners are pushing families towards making unsuitable purchases according to City Minister Glen; making it the first time the sector has been regulated. (Times/Newswires)

Whitbread (WTB LN) – Co. has formally proposed a render offer to return up to GBP 2bln to shareholders. (Newswires)

Wirecard (WDI GY) – CEO expects an “outstanding” H1 2019. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) - Co. and Merck’s (MRK) Lynparza has helped patients with advanced pancreatic cancer go nearly twice as long without disease worsening. (Newswires)

Total (FP FP) – Co. have signed an agreement to acquire Toshiba (6052 JP) to acquire their LNG portfolio (Newswires)

Deutz (DEZ GY) – Co. have begun a JV with Sany. Co. guide FY19 revenue EUR 500mln for 2022. (Newswires)

Veolia Environment (VIE FP) – Co. have announced the termination of their liquid contract, and the implementation of a new liquidity contract. (Newswires)

Total (FP FP) - Co. have signed an agreement with Ineos and Saudi Armaco to build Ineos' first Middle-East plants, Ineos are to invest USD 2bln in Saudi Arabia. (Newswires)

French Energy Names - French Environment Minister de Rugy has stated that from 2020 they will have a new method for the calculation of power prices. (Newswires) 

WPP (WPP LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

3rd June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded negative with risk appetite subdued as the US faces a 2-front trade war against China and Mexico, although stronger than expected Caixin PMI data helped limit losses in China. Nonetheless, a risk averse tone was seen from the reopen after China released a white paper that blamed the US for the setback of trade talks which pressured US equity futures to extend on the losses from Wall St’s worst May performance since 2010. ASX 200 (-1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.4%) declined with the energy sector the underperformer in Australia after the recent oil slump, while safe-haven currency flows weighed on Tokyo stocks and with weakness in SoftBank exacerbated on reports of funding difficulties for its next USD 100bln tech fund. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were initially higher after the PBoC maintained net liquidity through CNY 80bln of reverse repos and after Chinese Caixin Manufacturing topped estimates, although the gains were short-lived as trade concerns remained heavily in focus with China playing the blame game, while it is also set to draft its own blacklist of 'unreliable' entities and probe FedEx over possible infringement of Huawei’s legal rights regarding rerouted packages.

 

FTSE

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co. has reported data which suggests that its push into early-stage cancer treatments is yielding results. CEO noted that its strategy is now paying off. (FT)

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) – Co. is planning to set up FX e-trading and pricing engine in Singapore which is expected to launch in Q1 next year. (Newswires)

FTSE 100 reshuffle – easyJet (EZJ LN) are set to fall out of the index this week, whilst JD Sports (JD/ LN) is almost certain to be elevated to the blue-chip status. Other companies at risk of dropping include Just Eat (EAT LN), ITV (ITV LN), Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN). Marks & Spencer (MKS LN) are expected to retain its blue-chip status this quarter, although analyst note that it remains the most vulnerable in future reshuffles. (FT)

UK Retail Names – Amazon (AMZN) are to open 10 shops in the UK as part of a pilot test, with the first opening today in Manchester, stores are to help digital businesses with high-street success. Spokesman stated that Co. will not profit from the scheme. (CityAM)

Telecom Names – Two UK PM Candidates have reportedly stated they would not allow Huawei into the UK’s telecoms network; with other MP’s expressing concerns over the Co’s involvement in the UK telecom network. (Times)

Provident Financial (PFG LN) – Aberdeen Standard Investment, who own a 3.1% stake in the Co., have stated they will not accept Non-Standard Finance’s (NSF LN) offer for the Co. (Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Infineon (IFX GY) – Co. are to acquire Cypress Semiconductor Corp for USD 23.85/shr, corresponding to an enterprise value of EUR 9bln. Co. boards have already consented to the acquisition. Infineon shareholders are expected to benefit from the earnings accretion begging in the first full fiscal year after closing, which is expected by the end of 2019 or early 2020. (Newswires)

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Private equity firm BC Partners are reportedly exploring a joint bid for Co.’s animal medicine division. Sources stated the BC Partners could team up with either a rival buyout firm or a sovereign wealth fund for the Bayer unit, which could fetch up to EUR 8bln and is likely to be one of Europe’s largest buyouts since the financial crisis. (FT) 

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY)/UniCredit (UCG IM) – Co’s have moved some of their swaps trades to Frankfurt from London. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

CAC

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM)/ Renault (RNO FP) – Fiat Chrysler are reportedly discussion a Renault special dividend and stronger job guarantees in an attempt to persuade the French government to back the proposed merger, according to sources. (Newswires)

Airline names – The global airline industry is expected to record its lowest profit in five years, according to the International Air Transport Association citing a fuel cost rise and weakening world trade. (The Guardian) Elsewhere, Boeing (BA) have informed the Federal Aviation Administration that certain 737Max and 737NG wing components [leading edge slats] may have been improperly manufactured, FAA are planning to issue an order requiring operators of the plans worldwide to identify and replace the improper parts. Believed that 179Max and 133NG planes are affected. FAA state that complete failure of the components would not result in aircraft loss but could lead to in-flight damage. In response Boeing have notified plane operators and are sending replacement parts. (Newswires/CitiAM)

BROKER MOVES

PIRELLI (PIRC IM) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT BERENBERG

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – New Capmatinib investigational data and Noval Canakinumab clinical trials show growing strength in lunch cancer innovation. (Newswires)

Roche (ROG SW) – Co’s Xolair significantly reduced nasal polyps and congestion symptoms in adults with chronic Rhinosinusitis, as shown by a Phase III study. (Newswires)

Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) – Co. has appointed Tang Zhenyi has its chief executive for China, as the Co. attempts to expand its business in the region. (FT)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA 

Danske Bank (DANKSE DC) – LHV are seeking to acquire the Co’s unit involved with Estonian private loans for EUR 410mln, according to a statement. (Newswires)

 

US

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 3rd June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  1. A subdued start to the week for Asian indices as China released a White Paper blaming the US for trade talks deteriorating, and are to create an unreliable entity list
  2. In FX, the DXY remains below the 98.0 level as the US faces a two-front trade war; while, EUR and GBP are benefiting from the USD weakness
  3. Looking ahead, highlights include EZ, UK and US mfg PMIs, ISM mfg PMI, Fed’s Quarles, Barkin and Bullard

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded negatively with risk appetite subdued as the US faces a 2-front trade war against China and Mexico, although stronger than expected Caixin PMI data helped limit losses in China. Nonetheless, a risk averse tone was seen from the reopen after China released a white paper that blamed the US for the setback of trade talks which pressured US equity futures to extend on the losses from Wall St’s worst May performance since 2010. ASX 200 (-1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.4%) declined with the energy sector the underperformer in Australia after the recent oil slump, while safe-haven currency flows weighed on Tokyo stocks and with weakness in SoftBank exacerbated on reports of funding difficulties for its next USD 100bln tech fund. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were initially higher after the PBoC maintained net liquidity through CNY 80bln of reverse repos and after Chinese Caixin Manufacturing topped estimates, although the gains were short-lived as trade concerns remained heavily in focus with China playing the blame game, while it is also set to draft its own blacklist of 'unreliable' entities and probe FedEx over possible infringement of Huawei’s legal rights regarding rerouted packages. Finally, 10yr JGBs were steady with only marginal gains seen despite the widespread risk aversion and the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 800bln in up to 5yr JGBs.

China State Council Information Office released a white paper which formalized its position on trade negotiations and stated that the US government bears the responsibility for setback in trade talks, while it also noted that China does not want a trade war but is not afraid of one either. However, China also suggested negotiations remain a priority and State Councillor/Defence Minister Wei Fenghe said both sides should follow the consensus by the 2 heads of state and promote a relationship involving coordination, cooperation and stability, while a researcher at the state-backed think tank China Center for International Economic Exchanges suggested China “is expressing its wish to work together”. (Newswires/WSJ)

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repo for a net neutral position on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8896 (Prev. 6.8992)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (May) 50.2 vs. Exp. 50.0 (Prev. 50.2). (Newswires)

UK officials alleged that a security test on Huawei 5G equipment was rigged by China to make it look safer. (Telegraph)

UK/EU

UK Foreign Minister Hunt said no-deal must be kept on the table but does not want to have to choose between no-deal and no Brexit. (Newswires) Conservative leadership candidate Leadsom says that she will not look to renegotiate the Brexit deal and insisted she would pursue a managed no deal if Conservative MPs and members back her as the next PM. (Guardian). Elsewhere, fellow leadership contender Javid has ruled out the prospect of carrying out a 2nd referendum or revoking Article 50. (Sky News) UK Environment Secretary Gove is reportedly to be considering an additional extension of the Brexit process, an idea which has attracted backlash from Tory members stating that a delay to Brexit will lead to opposition Labour Leader Corbyn becoming PM. While a cabinet minister has stated that Gove is likely to acquire strong support, as he become the ‘compromise candidate’. (Times/Telegraph) UK Health Secretary Hancock has published a five-point plan for leaving the EU, which proposes a time limit to the Irish backstop; a source close to Hancock states that European level Officials have been open to his plan regarding a time limited backstop. (Telegraph)

Northern Ireland’s DUP could call on the future UK PM to commit to seeking “alternative arrangements” to the Brexit backstop plan for when their agreement with the government comes up for “review” this summer. (FT)

Germany’s SPD party leader and ruling coalition partner Andrea Nahles resigned; German Chancellor Merkel says her coalition government will continue despite the setback. (BBC/Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Austria at 'AA+'; Outlook Positive. (Newswires)

FX

 

DXY remained subdued after its drop below the 98.00 level on Friday as the tariff announcement on Mexico weighed on NAFTA currencies and with the greenback also pressured by declining yields, while Goldman Sachs was also bearish on the US economy in which the bank lowered its US Q2 GDP growth estimate to 1.1% from 1.3% and sees an increasing chance of a Fed rate cut but not enough to include it in its baseline scenario. Elsewhere, the trade concerns spurred safe-haven flows into JPY which dragged USD/JPY to the bottom end of the 108.00 handle, while EUR/USD and GBP/USD also extended on Friday’s gains amid the USD-woes. AUD/USD was also lifted despite the anticipation for a looming rate cut by the RBA tomorrow and NZD/USD gained in the absence of participants in New Zealand for holiday, as antipodeans took their cue from CNH after the better than expected Chinese PMI data and stronger fix by the PBoC.

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures below the USD 53.00/bbl and at 4-month lows as ongoing trade concerns triggered a further slippage in oil which had already declined over 5% on Friday, while geopolitical news flow including a strike by Israel on an Iran-linked base in Syria and Iran dismissing US suggestions to come to the table have failed to spur prices. Elsewhere, gold extended on gains above the USD 1300/oz level amid the subdued greenback and safe-haven demand, whilst copper was indecisive as pressure from the risk averse tone was counterbalanced by better than expected Chinese PMI data.

Baker Hughes (May 31) US oil rigs +3 at 800 (prev. 797), US nat gas rigs -2 at 184 (prev. 182), total US rigs +1 at 984 (prev. 983). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US is prepared to talk to Iran without pre-conditions about its nuclear program but that Iran needs to behave normally, although Iran dismissed the offer a word-play. (Newswires)

US

US 5yr yields fell to sub-2% last week, the 3m/10yr spread moved further into inversion (resulting in more commentary about the risks of recession over a 12-24 month horizon), and some data surprised to the downside, seeing the market price in three Fed rate cuts by the end of 2020. The fixed income bid was also supported by a slide in equities, although month-end models had suggest positive inflows into stocks. And the latest US measures against Mexico have added to Treasury upside as we close out the week; With 2s, 5s sub-2%, 7s are a couple of basis points away. Bund yields fell in sympathy, seeing German 10yr yields flirt with fresh all-time lows. Comments from Clarida on Thursday and the aforementioned risk-off were underpinning the bid on Friday. At settlement, the curve had bull-flattened, though major curve spreads were steeper (notably the 2s20s widened 6bps, 2s10s +5bps, 5s30s +3bps, 2s5s +3bps). US T-note futures (M9) settled +22 ticks at 126-12.

US President Trump tweeted that Mexico is sending a big delegation to talk about the border and suggested that the problem is that they’ve been “talking” for 25 years and we want action not talk. President Trump also suggested they could solve the border crisis in one day if they so desired but added that our companies and jobs are coming back to the USA. (Twitter) Furthermore, Trump has confirmed that the US will end preferential trade status for India this week. (BBC)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer was said to have opposed new Mexican tariffs and argued that it could harm USMCA, while US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin was also said to be against new measures against Mexico, according to sources. (WSJ/CNBC)

US President Trump said White House Economic Adviser Hassett will be leaving shortly and that a replacement will be announced when he returns to the US. (Twitter)

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) maintained forecast for economic growth at 2% and said trade discussions are creating uncertainty in the economy, while she added her stance is to be patient and wait what the details of the trade discussions are. (Newswires)

Trade

China State Council Information Office released a white paper which formalized its position on trade negotiations and stated that the US government bears the responsibility for setback in trade talks and noted that China does not want a trade war but is not afraid of one either. China also suggested negotiations remain a priority in which China State Councillor and Defence Minister Wei Fenghe said both sides should follow the consensus by the 2 heads of state and promote a relationship involving coordination, cooperation and stability, while a researcher at the state-backed think tank China Center for International Economic Exchanges suggested China is expressing its wish to work together. (Newswires/WSJ)

Chinese Commerce Ministry said it will draft a list of 'unreliable' entities which targets foreign players that harm the interest of Chinese firms. In related news, China Global Times Editor tweeted that based on what he knows, China will take major retaliatory measures against the US placing Huawei and other Chinese companies on entity list, while he added that Beijing will not wait passively and more countermeasures will follow although he thinks only those foreign Co.s that have cut off supply chains will be put on the China entity list. (Newswires/Twitter)

US customs agents formally began to collect 25% tariffs on USD 200bln list of Chinese goods arriving at US seaports, while China's higher tariffs on US goods on USD 60bln target list took effect at 00:00 local time on June 1st. (Newswires)
